title: The controversial origins of the Encyclopedia - Addison Anderson

multiple-choice.question: Who was Denis Diderot paired with to co-edit the French encyclopedia?

options.label: A
options.text: Jean Jacques Rousseau

options.label: B
options.text: Jean le Rond d'Alembert

options.label: C
options.text: Louis de Jaucourt

options.label: D
options.text: Voltaire

multiple-choice.question: What was the original task assigned to Denis Diderot by publisher Andr√© le Breton in 1745?

options.label: A
options.text: To write an essay about a philosopher's death bed rejection of God

options.label: B
options.text: To adapt the English cyclopedia for French subscribers

options.label: C
options.text: To author a pornographic novel

options.label: D
options.text: To translate a book on anatomy

multiple-choice.question: How did Diderot organize the encyclopedia, and what system did he adapt for this purpose?

options.label: A
options.text: He organized it alphabetically and adapted the Dewey Decimal System

options.label: B
options.text: He organized it chronologically and adapted the Library of Congress Classification

options.label: C
options.text: He organized it based on the mind's approaches to reality and adapted Francis Bacon's "Classification of Knowledge"

options.label: D
options.text: He organized it by subject and adapted the Universal Decimal Classification

multiple-choice.question: What was the significance of Jean Jacques Rousseau's entry on political economy in the encyclopedia?

options.label: A
options.text: It was a critique of Diderot's views on politics

options.label: B
options.text: It was a summary of his book "The Social Contract"

options.label: C
options.text: It contained ideas he would later develop further in "The Social Contract"

options.label: D
options.text: It was a rebuttal to Voltaire's views on politics

multiple-choice.question: Why was the encyclopedia banned by King Louis XV and condemned by Pope Clement XIII?

options.label: A
options.text: Because it was too expensive to produce

options.label: B
options.text: Because it contained recipes and was considered frivolous

options.label: C
options.text: Because it was considered "dangerous" and "reprehensible" due to its radical ideas

options.label: D
options.text: Because it was written in French and not Latin

multiple-choice.question: How did Diderot manage to continue publishing the encyclopedia despite the ban and condemnation?

options.label: A
options.text: He smuggled proofs outside France with the help of allies in the French Regime

options.label: B
options.text: He changed the content to make it less radical

options.label: C
options.text: He published it under a pseudonym

options.label: D
options.text: He stopped publishing it altogether

multiple-choice.question: What was the significance of the encyclopedia in the context of the French Enlightenment?

options.label: A
options.text: It was a rejection of the Enlightenment values

options.label: B
options.text: It was a cornerstone of the Enlightenment, promoting independent investigative reasoning

options.label: C
options.text: It was a critique of the Enlightenment thinkers

options.label: D
options.text: It was a summary of the Enlightenment ideas

multiple-choice.question: What can be inferred about Diderot's views on politics and society based on his entries in the encyclopedia?

options.label: A
options.text: He was a supporter of the divine right of kings

options.label: B
options.text: He believed in the importance of great disparity in wealth

options.label: C
options.text: He was a proponent of independent investigative reasoning and critical of absolute power

options.label: D
options.text: He was a conservative who opposed change

multiple-choice.question: How did the publication of the encyclopedia reflect the changing times and popular opinions in France?

options.label: A
options.text: It marked a shift from secular to religious authority

options.label: B
options.text: It reflected a migration of popular opinions from pulpit and pew to cafe, salon, and press

options.label: C
options.text: It was a rejection of the emerging middle class

options.label: D
options.text: It was a call to return to traditional values

multiple-choice.question: What can be said about the tone and style of the encyclopedia, based on Diderot's entry about the plant aguaxima?

options.label: A
options.text: It is formal and objective

options.label: B
options.text: It is irrepressibly human and humorous

options.label: C
options.text: It is dry and academic

options.label: D
options.text: It is critical and satirical

title: The science of skin color - Angela Koine Flynn

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary pigment responsible for giving skin and hair its color?

options.label: A
options.text: Eumelanin

options.label: B
options.text: Pheomelanin

options.label: C
options.text: Melanin

options.label: D
options.text: Rhodopsin

multiple-choice.question: Describe the primary function of melanin in human skin.

options.label: A
options.text: To produce vitamin D

options.label: B
options.text: To shield cells from damage caused by UV light

options.label: C
options.text: To strengthen bones

options.label: D
options.text: To cause skin cancer

multiple-choice.question: A person with fair skin is more susceptible to sunburn due to lower levels of melanin. What can they do to protect themselves from the sun's UV rays?

options.label: A
options.text: Use sunscreen with high SPF

options.label: B
options.text: Stay indoors during peak sun hours

options.label: C
options.text: Wear protective clothing

options.label: D
options.text: All of the above

multiple-choice.question: Analyze the relationship between skin color and vitamin D production. How do individuals with darker skin tones adapt to lower levels of sunlight?

options.label: A
options.text: They produce more melanin to shield cells from damage

options.label: B
options.text: They produce less melanin to allow for more UV absorption

options.label: C
options.text: They migrate to areas with more direct sunlight

options.label: D
options.text: They develop stronger bones to compensate for lower vitamin D levels

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the deadly cancer that can form in the skin's melanocytes due to severe DNA damage caused by UV light?

options.label: A
options.text: Melanoma

options.label: B
options.text: Skin cancer

options.label: C
options.text: Rickets

options.label: D
options.text: Vitamin D deficiency

multiple-choice.question: How did the skin color of humans change as they migrated northward from Africa and into Europe and Asia?

options.label: A
options.text: It became darker due to increased melanin production

options.label: B
options.text: It became lighter due to decreased melanin production

options.label: C
options.text: It remained the same due to genetic stability

options.label: D
options.text: It varied randomly due to genetic drift

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the light-sensitive receptors that stimulate the production of melanin in response to UV light?

options.label: A
options.text: Rhodopsin

options.label: B
options.text: Melanocytes

options.label: C
options.text: Eumelanin

options.label: D
options.text: Pheomelanin

multiple-choice.question: Synthesize the information about skin color adaptation and vitamin D production. How do these factors influence human survival in different environments?

options.label: A
options.text: Darker skin tones are advantageous in areas with high levels of sunlight, while lighter skin tones are beneficial in areas with low levels of sunlight

options.label: B
options.text: Lighter skin tones are advantageous in areas with high levels of sunlight, while darker skin tones are beneficial in areas with low levels of sunlight

options.label: C
options.text: Skin color has no impact on human survival in different environments

options.label: D
options.text: Vitamin D production is not influenced by skin color

multiple-choice.question: Evaluate the statement: "Skin color is a reflection of character." Do you agree or disagree, and why?

options.label: A
options.text: Agree, because skin color is a determinant of personality traits

options.label: B
options.text: Disagree, because skin color is an adaptive trait that has no relation to character

options.label: C
options.text: Agree, because skin color influences an individual's moral values

options.label: D
options.text: Disagree, because skin color is a fixed trait that cannot be changed

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary benefit of UV light for human health, despite its potential to cause skin damage?

options.label: A
options.text: It produces vitamin D, which strengthens bones

options.label: B
options.text: It causes skin cancer, which can be treated with medication

options.label: C
options.text: It leads to melanoma, which can be prevented with sunscreen

options.label: D
options.text: It has no benefits for human health

title: How to speak so that people want to listen

multiple-choice.question: What does the speaker consider the most powerful sound in the world?

options.label: A
options.text: Music

options.label: B
options.text: Animal sounds

options.label: C
options.text: The human voice

options.label: D
options.text: Natural sounds

multiple-choice.question: According to the speaker, what is one reason people don't listen to others?

options.label: A
options.text: They are not interested in the topic

options.label: B
options.text: They are distracted by their surroundings

options.label: C
options.text: They know they are being judged and found wanting

options.label: D
options.text: They are not feeling well

multiple-choice.question: What is the term the speaker uses to describe the act of speaking ill of someone who is not present?

options.label: A
options.text: Negativity

options.label: B
options.text: Gossip

options.label: C
options.text: Complaining

options.label: D
options.text: Judging

multiple-choice.question: How can one's tone of voice affect the way their message is received?

options.label: A
options.text: A high-pitched voice is more authoritative

options.label: B
options.text: A low-pitched voice is more trustworthy

options.label: C
options.text: A loud voice is more persuasive

options.label: D
options.text: A soft voice is more attention-grabbing

multiple-choice.question: What does the speaker suggest as a way to make one's speech more powerful?

options.label: A
options.text: To use more complex vocabulary

options.label: B
options.text: To speak more quickly

options.label: C
options.text: To stand on the four cornerstones of honesty, authenticity, integrity, and love

options.label: D
options.text: To use more gestures

multiple-choice.question: What is the term the speaker uses to describe the sing-song or meta-language used in conversation?

options.label: A
options.text: Prosody

options.label: B
options.text: Timbre

options.label: C
options.text: Register

options.label: D
options.text: Pitch

multiple-choice.question: According to the speaker, what is the effect of complaining on others?

options.label: A
options.text: It makes them feel more positive

options.label: B
options.text: It makes them feel more empathetic

options.label: C
options.text: It spreads misery

options.label: D
options.text: It has no effect

multiple-choice.question: How can one's breathing and posture affect the timbre of their voice?

options.label: A
options.text: It can make their voice sound more nasal

options.label: B
options.text: It can make their voice sound more rich and smooth

options.label: C
options.text: It can make their voice sound more high-pitched

options.label: D
options.text: It can make their voice sound more monotone

multiple-choice.question: What is the term the speaker uses to describe the act of imposing one's sound on others carelessly and inconsiderately?

options.label: A
options.text: Sodcasting

options.label: B
options.text: Broadcasting

options.label: C
options.text: Gossiping

options.label: D
options.text: Complaining

multiple-choice.question: According to the speaker, what would be the result of creating sound consciously, consuming sound consciously, and designing environments consciously for sound?

options.label: A
options.text: A world with more noise and distractions

options.label: B
options.text: A world with more conflict and misunderstandings

options.label: C
options.text: A world that sounds beautiful and where understanding is the norm

options.label: D
options.text: A world with less creativity and self-expression

title: Every kid needs a champion - Rita Pierson

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's profession, and how many years of experience do they have in that field?

options.label: A
options.text: Teacher, 20 years

options.label: B
options.text: Educator, 40 years

options.label: C
options.text: School Administrator, 30 years

options.label: D
options.text: Counselor, 10 years

multiple-choice.question: According to James Comer, what is essential for significant learning to occur?

options.label: A
options.text: A well-structured lesson plan

options.label: B
options.text: A significant relationship

options.label: C
options.text: A conducive learning environment

options.label: D
options.text: A qualified teacher

multiple-choice.question: A colleague of the speaker believes that their role is only to teach a lesson, regardless of whether the students like them or not. What is the speaker's response to this?

options.label: A
options.text: The speaker agrees with the colleague

options.label: B
options.text: The speaker disagrees, stating that kids don't learn from people they don't like

options.label: C
options.text: The speaker suggests that the colleague should try to build relationships with the students

options.label: D
options.text: The speaker ignores the colleague's comment

multiple-choice.question: What is an example of a simple yet effective way to build relationships with students, as suggested by Stephen Covey?

options.label: A
options.text: Apologizing to students when necessary

options.label: B
options.text: Providing individualized attention to each student

options.label: C
options.text: Using positive reinforcement techniques

options.label: D
options.text: All of the above

multiple-choice.question: The speaker recounts an experience where they taught a lesson incorrectly and had to apologize to the students the next day. What was the students' reaction to the apology?

options.label: A
options.text: They were upset and angry

options.label: B
options.text: They were shocked and appreciative

options.label: C
options.text: They were indifferent and unresponsive

options.label: D
options.text: They were confused and unsure

multiple-choice.question: What strategy did the speaker use to raise the self-esteem of a group of academically deficient students?

options.label: A
options.text: Providing extra tutoring and support

options.label: B
options.text: Encouraging them to participate in extracurricular activities

options.label: C
options.text: Telling them that they were chosen to be in the speaker's class because they were the best students

options.label: D
options.text: Focusing on their strengths and abilities

multiple-choice.question: What is the significance of the "+2" and smiley face on the student's paper, despite them missing 18 out of 20 questions?

options.label: A
options.text: It indicates that the student is failing and needs to improve

options.label: B
options.text: It suggests that the student is on the right track and should continue their efforts

options.label: C
options.text: It shows that the teacher is being too lenient and should be more strict

options.label: D
options.text: It implies that the student is not trying hard enough

multiple-choice.question: What is an example of how the speaker's mother demonstrated her commitment to building relationships with her students?

options.label: A
options.text: She provided extra tutoring and support outside of class

options.label: B
options.text: She made home visits and provided basic necessities for her students

options.label: C
options.text: She encouraged her students to participate in extracurricular activities

options.label: D
options.text: She focused on their academic achievements and progress

multiple-choice.question: According to the speaker, what is the key to making a difference in the lives of students?

options.label: A
options.text: Providing a rigorous and challenging curriculum

options.label: B
options.text: Building relationships and connections with students

options.label: C
options.text: Using innovative and engaging teaching methods

options.label: D
options.text: Focusing on academic achievement and progress

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's message to educators and teachers?

options.label: A
options.text: That teaching is a tough and impossible job

options.label: B
options.text: That building relationships with students is not important

options.label: C
options.text: That educators have the power to make a difference in the lives of their students

options.label: D
options.text: That academic achievement is the only thing that matters

options.label: A
options.text: To synthesize proteins

options.label: B
options.text: To store genetic information

options.label: C
options.text: To generate energy for the cell

options.label: D

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: D

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: Temperature

options.label: C
options.text: pH level

options.text: Increased crop yields

options.label: B
options.text: Improved disease resistance

options.label: B
options.text: Photosynthesis

options.label: C

options.label: D

options.label: C
options.text: Random chance

options.label: C

options.label: B
options.text: Increased energy independence

options.label: C

title: How to make your writing funnier - Cheri Steinkellner

multiple-choice.question: What are the basic ingredients of great storytelling, including comedy writing?

options.label: A
options.text: Who, what, when

options.label: B
options.text: Who, what, when, where, why, and how

options.label: C
options.text: What, where, why

options.label: D
options.text: Why, how, when

multiple-choice.question: Which of the following is a Commedia Dell'Arte character type?

options.label: A
options.text: The brave warrior

options.label: B
options.text: The loveable loser

options.label: C
options.text: The wise king

options.label: D
options.text: The strong athlete

multiple-choice.question: According to the transcript, what is the secret to humor according to Aristotle?

options.label: A
options.text: Surprise

options.label: B
options.text: Sarcasm

options.label: C
options.text: Irony

options.label: D
options.text: Exaggeration

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of drawing connections with a mind map in comedy writing?

options.label: A
options.text: To organize ideas

options.label: B
options.text: To create a story outline

options.label: C
options.text: To find incongruities and generate comedic material

options.label: D
options.text: To develop character traits

multiple-choice.question: How can shifting from observation to imagination help in generating comedic material?

options.label: A
options.text: By focusing on realistic situations

options.label: B
options.text: By asking "what if" and exploring new possibilities

options.label: C
options.text: By analyzing the audience's preferences

options.label: D
options.text: By using humor formulas

multiple-choice.question: What is the "rule of three" or "zig zig zag" in comedy writing?

options.label: A
options.text: Setting up an expected pattern and then flipping it

options.label: B
options.text: Creating a joke with three punchlines

options.label: C
options.text: Using three characters in a story

options.label: D
options.text: Writing three drafts of a script

multiple-choice.question: Why is humor considered subjective, according to the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: Because people have different senses of humor

options.label: B
options.text: Because comedy is a precise science

options.label: C
options.text: Because writers can predict what will be funny

options.label: D
options.text: Because humor is culturally specific

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of incorporating words with a k-sound in comedy writing?

options.label: A
options.text: To create a serious tone

options.label: B
options.text: To add complexity to the story

options.label: C
options.text: To catch the audience's ears and create a comical effect

options.label: D
options.text: To distract from the punchline

multiple-choice.question: How can a writer use their personal experiences to create comedic material?

options.label: A
options.text: By writing about their successes

options.label: B
options.text: By imagining their frustrating experiences happening to a character

options.label: C
options.text: By analyzing their favorite comedies

options.label: D
options.text: By using humor formulas

multiple-choice.question: What is the most important rule of writing funny, according to the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: Have a clear structure

options.label: B
options.text: Use humor formulas

options.label: C
options.text: Analyze the audience's preferences

options.label: D
options.text: Have fun

title: The immortal cells of Henrietta Lacks - Robin Bulleri

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary purpose of growing human cells in a lab?

options.label: A
options.text: To test new treatments on patients

options.label: B
options.text: To study how cells function and understand how diseases develop

options.label: C
options.text: To create new vaccines for diseases

options.label: D
options.text: To clone human cells

multiple-choice.question: What was unique about the tumor sample received by George Gey in 1951?

options.label: A
options.text: It was a typical sample of cancer cells

options.label: B
options.text: It was a sample of a benign tumor

options.label: C
options.text: Some of its cells continued to divide indefinitely

options.label: D
options.text: It was a sample of a tumor that had already been treated

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the first immortal human cell line, and who is it named after?

options.label: A
options.text: HeLa, named after Dr. George Gey

options.label: B
options.text: HeLa, named after Henrietta Lacks

options.label: C
options.text: HL-1, named after Dr. Jonas Salk

options.label: D
options.text: HL-1, named after Henrietta Lacks

multiple-choice.question: What is the process called when normal human cells self-destruct after a certain number of divisions?

options.label: A
options.text: Apoptosis

options.label: B
options.text: Mitosis

options.label: C
options.text: Meiosis

options.label: D
options.text: Telomerase

multiple-choice.question: How did scientists use HeLa cells to help develop a vaccine for polio?

options.label: A
options.text: HeLa cells were used to test the vaccine on patients

options.label: B
options.text: HeLa cells were used to replicate the polio virus, allowing for testing of the vaccine

options.label: C
options.text: HeLa cells were used to create a new strain of the polio virus

options.label: D
options.text: HeLa cells were not used in the development of the polio vaccine

multiple-choice.question: What is the enzyme that helps cancer cells evade destruction by repairing their DNA, which was first discovered in HeLa cells?

options.label: A
options.text: Telomerase

options.label: B
options.text: Apoptase

options.label: C
options.text: Mitase

options.label: D
options.text: DNAse

multiple-choice.question: What is the result of HeLa cells' ability to travel on almost any surface and invade cultures of other cells?

options.label: A
options.text: They are unable to survive outside of a lab

options.label: B
options.text: They are only able to grow in specific conditions

options.label: C
options.text: They can take over other cell cultures like weeds

options.label: D
options.text: They are only able to grow in the human body

multiple-choice.question: Evaluate the ethics of using HeLa cells without Henrietta Lacks' or her family's consent. Was it:

options.label: A
options.text: Completely justified, as it led to numerous scientific breakthroughs

options.label: B
options.text: Somewhat justified, but the lack of consent is a concern

options.label: C
options.text: Not justified, as it disregarded the rights and autonomy of Henrietta Lacks and her family

options.label: D
options.text: Not relevant, as the cells were taken from a tumor and not directly from Henrietta Lacks

multiple-choice.question: Synthesize the information about HeLa cells and their impact on science. What can be concluded about their significance?

options.label: A
options.text: They have had a limited impact on our understanding of cancer and diseases

options.label: B
options.text: They have only been used in a few studies and have not contributed significantly to scientific knowledge

options.label: C
options.text: They have revolutionized our understanding of cancer, virology, and genetics, and have led to numerous breakthroughs and discoveries

options.label: D
options.text: They have only been used in the development of vaccines and have not contributed to other areas of science

multiple-choice.question: Analyze the relationship between HeLa cells and the development of treatments for diseases. How have HeLa cells contributed to this area of research?

options.label: A
options.text: HeLa cells have only been used to study the behavior of cancer cells and have not contributed to the development of treatments

options.label: B
options.text: HeLa cells have been used to test new treatments, but their contribution has been limited

options.label: C
options.text: HeLa cells have been instrumental in the development of treatments for diseases, including the polio vaccine and the HPV vaccine

options.label: D
options.text: HeLa cells have not been used in the development of treatments for diseases

title: Zika Virus Spreading in Most of the Americas

multiple-choice.question: Who is the author of the poem "The Road Not Taken"?

options.label: A
options.text: Edgar Allan Poe

options.label: B
options.text: Robert Frost

options.label: C
options.text: William Shakespeare

options.label: D
options.text: Emily Dickinson

multiple-choice.question: What is the central theme of the poem "The Road Not Taken"?

options.label: A
options.text: Love and relationships

options.label: B
options.text: Choice and its consequences

options.label: C
options.text: Nature and the environment

options.label: D
options.text: War and conflict

multiple-choice.question: What literary device does the author use to add depth and complexity to the poem's themes?

options.label: A
options.text: Alliteration and assonance

options.label: B
options.text: Symbolism, imagery, and metaphor

options.label: C
options.text: Personification and hyperbole

options.label: D
options.text: Simile and onomatopoeia

multiple-choice.question: How can the speaker's decision to take the less-traveled road be interpreted?

options.label: A
options.text: As a celebration of his individuality

options.label: B
options.text: As a regretful decision

options.label: C
options.text: As a sign of indecision

options.label: C
options.text: A shift in ocean currents and weather patterns

options.label: D
options.text: A reduction in biodiversity in shallow tropical seas

multiple-choice.question: According to the transcript, what is the unique ability that makes humans capable of driving mass extinctions, but also enables them to prevent them?

options.label: A
options.text: Their ability to adapt to changing environments

options.label: B
options.text: Their capacity for complex social behavior

options.label: C
options.text: Their ability to learn from past events and apply that knowledge to mitigate their impact

options.label: D
options.text: Their ability to develop and use advanced technologies
